text: The Greeks are seemingly confusing but really simple. And once you know how to use them, they become second nature to help you build smarter trades. The goal of this video is to walk you through a step-by-step process on how you can default on what makes the most sense based on what you're trying to do for an individual trade so that the Greeks seem way less overwhelming. And this is stuff that you can quite literally practically apply whenever you feel like it. The way to think about the Greeks is they're like the instrument cluster to your car. It gives you a lot of information. It tells you if your car is running high and potentially going to overheat. It tells you if your oil pressure is good, if your oil temperature is good, so on and so forth. That is exactly what the Greeks do. So they can seem overwhelming but really they just give you information on how an option or grouping of options known as a structure or strategy is going to behave. So let's talk about basics here. Now I have a video that goes pretty deep into detail on the Greeks. So I'm going to spend very little time on the basics. And I want to speak more so from the practical application of using them to build smarter trades. But for those that need a reminder on the basics, you can gloss over this very quickly. And you will be essentially

The way to think about first order, second order, third order simply pertains to what does the Greek measure. Notice how for delta, theta, Vega, row, it has everything to do with premium rates of change relative to something pertaining to the option. Gamma ramps up as we get closer to expiration because again, we just talked about this with delta. Delta has to make a choice. And gamma measures the rate of change of delta. text: a lot of these metrics, theta, Vega, they're relative to the time frame, but then they're also relative to the total premium of an option. So here's the cliff note summary. If I buy an option that is a higher delta, it's going to be more expensive, but it's going to move closer for a dollar for dollar move in the underlying. It's also going to compound less. What that means is this one delta, there's no compounding value. It's going to move one dollar for each dollar move in the underlying. And it's going to be more expensive as compared to something that might be cheaper that I can buy more of that starts at a 30 delta, but for each one dollar move in the underlying, it's going to gain five delta's. And then after another dollar move in the underlying, it's going to gain six delta's. So it compounds very, very quickly. So the trade off here is higher delta, moves better dollar for dollar, lower delta, depending on whatever gamma is, lower delta will be cheaper, but you can buy more of them. And then for gamma, we just naturally hit on some of that. Gamma is going to be higher the closer you are in time, which if you're correct, will allow you to compound faster if you're buying your option. But if you're wrong, your option is going to decay from delta decay as we get closer to expiration. So you can strike a

But if you're wrong, your option is going to decay from delta decay as we get closer to expiration. So you can strike a balance between these based on what kind of risk profile you're trying to achieve in your option. Now for theta, if you use, let's say, long options and you buy something that seven days to expiration, your theta as a gross value might be less, but as a percentage of what you bought into is going to be way more. The reason why this matters is because then as your 24 cents decays away from these 2.80 call options, well, that means that even if you get your dollar move and get 52 cents out of the delta, you're essentially paying 24 cents of that or 24 to counteract your theta decay. Now, if you go further out in time to avoid that, you're going to pay a larger gross amount. But you're going to get less gamma, you're going to get less of a compounding effect. So this is why for a lot of buying strategies, I prefer to going a little further out in time and at the money slash a little bit deeper in the money, typically targeting around a 70 delta. Because another example here is if I sell, let's say the same 30 delta option here that has seven days left to go, well, I'm getting 25 sense of theta. If I compare that to the 35s, I'm only getting 10. And then if I do compare that to something like the three days to expiration, same 30 delta, I'm getting 19. So all of these provide a slightly different amount of money. And again, once it's taken relative to the total premium, it makes a big difference.
